text: Hi team, is there any limitation in size when passing parameters to island?

Good morning, I tried this in several ways but it still doesn’t work, the error I get is the following:

Couldn’t find the requested POST XXX. Make sure your path is correct and that the function for POST XXX is deployed, and then try again.

Has anyone else besides Andrey and I experienced this? Help would be appreciated :sweat_smile:.

Hi all. We are trying to add HubSpot CTAs to a site built with React. The new CTAs interact with the main HubSpot tracking script but it appears we are having React hydration issues. The React HubSpot form library that we are using gets around these hydration errors by reloading the HubSpot forms script on each mount, but unfortunately it looks like the HubSpot CTA only uses the tracking script. Does anyone have a solve for this?
Are you using the CTA helper? <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-react/reference/cms-components.html#cta>
Thanks, this is really helpful!
We are not! I'll take a look

Is it correct that we can’t pass `widget_data` , e.g. page or website specific things, defined in fields, to react modules?
We have a global module full of “settings”, such as translations for error messages, and I’d like to have these values available in my React module.

We can’t set up a template and pass it through the `js_module` , since this React module is to be added in different contexts.
Please see <https://github.HubSpot.com/cms-react/reference/js-modules.html#hubldatatemplate> for situations where you need to pass information from the HubL context into CMS React modul.
Also `js_module` is deprecated, you should just use `module` if calling directly from a template

There are limitations on the island props being serializable, but I don’t think we have any explicit size limits (maybe there is some limitation in our infra somewhere that restricts size, but I’m not aware of that).

However, all data that you pass to an island will also need to be sent as serialized JSON to the browser (for to hydrate). So you need to be careful about the performance cost of that.
<@U06NTPTUT9R> would you mind giving more specifics on your use case?

would it be possible in a future HubSpot version to allow breakpoints to be configured other than mobile/tablet/desktop, by providing different names/icons/breakpoints to it (and more than 3 options)?

doing a bunch of HubL functions/queries in `hubl_data.hubl.html` will slow down page load I am assuming? Is there any concrete way to measure the impact? I want to see if querying against 5-10 items vs. 100 items makes a difference
Yes, “hubl data” will block the server render of the page. I believe you can get _a little_ timing insight in the HTML comments created by `?hsDebug=true`
cool, requests for `blog_recent_tag_posts` seem to run pretty fast based on `hsDebug`

assuming that this is the total for this module
```&quot;{% module 'blog_related_posts'          path='@pr...: 55 ms.&quot;: {```
that's "slow" compared to the other parts of the page but running a max or almost max number of `blog_recent_tag_posts`
<@UCY83QS6Q> are there any tricks you know to lessen the perceived load time when clicking on something? so far I'm messing around with the "active" link state

my serverless function times are kind of long:
```2024-04-15T19:01:43.170Z - SUCCESS - Execution Time: 1398ms
2024-04-15T19:55:36.922Z - SUCCESS - Execution Time: 3116ms

Has anyone tried/know if its possible to create fields that are dependant on one another, if for example I have a dropdown with some items would it be possible that the items the user chooses in the first dropdown would then become the options of the 2nd dropdown
Should be possible right?
The reason I’m asking is because I’m actually using this function, and it works wonderfully for passing module fields. But `widget_data` is empty, when passed through.
